segments.text: Now, what outfit were you with in the Corps of Cadets?
I was with the infantry.
What did you think about the hazing at A&M?
The what?
Hazing.
Oh, from old timers, I'd learned to expect that when I got down there.
I thought it was a kind of a foolish prankster type sort of thing that didn't contribute a goddamn thing to anything.
On the other side of things, I got involved in it also.
Why?
Well, I guess it's one of these things where you allow bad habits
or evil things to overcome sound judgment.
And that happens to you.
Like drowning out someone, you know.
I don't know whether you know what that is.
I never beat anybody with a paddle, but here's a guy trying to sleep and you go throw a bucket of water on him.
Why do you do that?
Well, had he done that to you,
I don't know who it was, but you'd think it was him.
What does that contribution mean?
Absolutely zero.
Or you have a bag full of water and somebody walks along and you drop it on his head from up on the roof.
I guess I can best say it's immaturity.
It's the sort of thing that happened with all children.
And you're still children when you do that.
You're not a man.
Men don't do those things to each other.
Isn't that right?
Men do not do those things to each other.
It's only children that does that.
And children are immature.
Did you learn anything from it?
Absolutely nothing.
Nothing.
Is that one of the things that you disliked about the Corps?
No, I really didn't dislike this, but it made no contribution.
Well, what did you like and dislike about the Corps of Cadets?
What I liked about the Corps of Cadets is
I think the most fascinating thing in the world for a man is to see one guy out as a leader and everybody else is studying there to replace him when he goes.
And the preciseness, the discipline involved.
That's what it's all about.
Learning to do things well.
And doing things well.
And doing it in such a fashion that other people see it and say, oh my God, aren't they great.
Aren't they good?
Look how they dress.
Look how he stands.
Look at his clothing.
Look at his whole posture.
Discipline.
That's what it's all about.
That's how you become a successful chairman of the board or president of United Technology or Martin Marietta Corporation or Sears and Roebuck or anything else.
And that is one thing this country has the least of, and that's leadership.
I used to stand on the platform at West Point and teach psychology of leadership, and I used to say, all you fellows are going to be leaders.
I was wrong about that.
Only one or two out of a hundred are going to be leaders.
You say leaders are made, not born.
I can't totally subscribe to that.
I can't totally subscribe to all leaders are made and not born.
Because you look into what I
see as a leader it is a leader has to have a personality he has to have a mannerism he has to have a posture he has to have a mind he has to have a heart
and a soul and he has to have principles of fair play and justice unselfish unbending relentless belief in principles and a burning desire to continue to learn

and you put all of that combination together and stand up then in front of a group of men of which they're all different from you and they're individuals and then you be able to communicate with them in such a fashion that they all understand exactly what it is you want done and then they go do it
That's leadership.
Now, you start looking at all those things, I have nothing to do with my personality.
I have nothing to do with my physical posture.
I have nothing to do with my physical makeup at all, the size of my feet, my hands, my nose, my face.
I have nothing to do with that.
I have nothing to do with
with, to a large degree, a mannerism.
The way I talk, the way I use my hands, the way I walk, and that's a motivating thing, an emotional thing, emotional.
It has nothing to do with that.
I do have a lot of things to do with the learning,
to detect, to represent principles, to build my own techniques, my own personal techniques which apply the principles based on my personality, statue, and the things that I had nothing to do with.
can foster adventure.
I can accept the inborn principle of challenge.
I can work like the devil to get rid of my selfish I think inborn characteristics.
And I can continue to discipline myself, which is study.
You see, discipline is so vital to everything.
Absolutely, no question about it.
Absolutely exactness.
See, discipline is learning to do things well, learning to do things

so well that they become habitual and automatic those good principles you never have to think about them okay you never have to think about those things and they become habitual and automatic you've learned them so well and you believe them so well then your mind is free to meet the ever-changing situations that happen about you that god only knows about that's going to happen
And you're prepared.
Then you are prepared.
You see?
For example, you teach a soldier to fire his rifle.
And he knows all there is to know about that rifle.

Then as he unexpectedly, or he may expect it, receives fire from the enemy, he doesn't have to go back and say, well, now, I wonder how I load this rifle I've got here because that guy's going to kill me here.
How do I load this thing?
Or what did that sergeant say about how you...
move this lever or that lever to make it shoot.
Well, he's dead.
That's a visual automatic.
It's like teaching a soldier.
You say there's a little roll in the terrain out here.
Now, you receive fire from out here on the battlefield.
The first thing you do is you take cover.
Cover?
Yeah.
Cover
in the mind of a soldier is cover from the fire.
Get behind something or down low so that that fire won't hit you.
Then you try to conceal yourself from the enemy.
Concealment is trying to protect yourself so he can't see you while you move to go after him.
Well, if you haven't learned those principles so well, you're going to be dead.
So life's not going to be very long, isn't it?
So this is what I'm talking about.
Squads right, squads east, squads left, whatever you want to call it, right and left, forward march, always step on your left foot, this on the fourth, and this same movement.
Now you said that one of the things that you liked about the Corps was the leadership possibility.
Were you a leader in the Corps?
Did you have an opportunity?
I was a squad leader in my company.
I was a best drill cadet in my company.
I was a sergeant.
I was a platoon sergeant.
I was a captain on the battalion staff.
and those were positions of leadership.
Now, you said that one of the things that you liked was the discipline.
Were there other things that you liked about the Corps?
Well, I liked the military subjects that they had.
There were practical subjects, life-saving subjects.
So you thought you got good instruction?
Oh, I got fantastic.

The best instruction I had was from those sergeants who had been in the military for 15, 20 years, and from the officers, and from what you get, not in the class, but from what you get from looking at the individual as an officer.
Those fellows were immaculate.
Those models.
They're models.
And they were immaculate.
And that's just an inspiration.
There wasn't any non-military professors there that wore Art Schaffner mark suits and all that sort of stuff.
And their shoes were shined and their hair immaculate and that sort of stuff.
You only see that in the military.
That's where you expect it.
That's what America expects, and that's what they deserve because it is different from the civilian life.
Were there any things about the Corps that you disliked?
We were an all-white school at that time.
And I suspect that if there had been black students at A&M, I don't know whether they had been able to be in the Corps or not.
I don't know.
I'm just speculating now.
I don't know.
But I had
nothing but admiration and respect for the military curriculum.
The way it was conducted I thought was by the ultimate of professionals and I guess that there is some harassment there about maybe you worked
for an hour and a half shining a buckle or something for us, and then for somebody to come by and say, well, you've got a dirty buckle there, you know, you don't go for that sort of stuff.
But that was immaturity sort of stuff amongst the people.
Now, in what way do you think that the Corps helped your career?
Well, it provided a way of life for me.
Sort of gave you the foundation of what the military would be like?
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
No question about it.
Absolutely.
I, uh, no question about that.
Were there any ways in which you think that being a member of the Corps of Cadets might have hurt your career in the long run?
No, I do not think so.
It was only helpful, only helpful.
And I think that is brought out by my following 36 years in the military.
Let's now talk about the quality of the product of Texas A&M, the second lieutenant.
uh tell me what what do you think are his strengths and weaknesses and perhaps you'd like to compare it with those of the west point second lieutenant

I think that most people will probably disagree with my comparisons and my method of comparing, but I think you get just as few military leaders, true leaders that go on to be general officers, I think you get just as few
true leaders out of West Point as you get out of Texas A&M.
Because you're second lieutenant that doesn't mean that you're a real leader.
You're called a platoon leader if you like with 40 men but let's look at it this way.
Second lieutenant out of A&M or out of
Citadel or out of VMI or out of the Air Force Academy or the Naval Academy or the Military Academy are the least experienced officers in the service, aren't they?
Okay.
And what are their responsibilities in the case of the Army?
We'll stick to the Army.
Who do they lead if they're going to lead?
They lead the least experienced soldiers in the Army.
So really what we're talking about here is the least experienced officer leading the least experienced enlisted men, which is a platoon of 25 to 40 people.
Now, this young officer ends up with an awesome responsibility.
And I want to tell you straight forward there isn't much leading going on.
And how can you expect the least experienced officer in the Army to lead the least experienced people in the Army?
How is he going to lead them?
Hell, he's been in the academic route for four years.
He's had us.
just a smattering of military and now here he is.
He needs a lot of help from the senior fellows with five or six years service in order for him and from the senior NCOs.
I guess what I'm saying is that he's just beginning
When he graduated from A&M as a second lieutenant or West Point as a second A&M, he's now prepared to go out and learn something about what this is all about.
And that's the reason why the attrition rate is so low at the Air Academy and Naval Academy and the Military Academy and amongst the regulars that leave Texas A&M.
The attrition rate is maybe
40-50% at the end of 10 years.
Why?
Well, they can't hack it.
They can't do it.
They don't like it.
They're in the wrong business.
Here's what General Abrams said to the Congress of the United States, and this is a matter of record, and I guess it's in about the
1973 congressional record.
He said out of 100,000 officers, we are looking for four or five, only four or five out of 100,000 that we can put at the right place at the right time
to influence the action and win the battle or the war.
He says, as was the case in Guadalcanal, as was the case at An Loc in Vietnam.
And I'm the guy he's talking about there.
So, if you can just get that number.
This goes back to what I said, the least thing we have
in our society is leadership.
Do you think that there's a higher probability that those four or five will come from Texas A&M or West Point?
Which school or does the ROTC program or the academy, do they have a higher probability?
They complement each other.
They complement each other very much because
At West Point, it's pure science and engineering, hard engineering sciences and that sort of thing.
Well, at Texas A&M, you may end up with a fellow that's a liberal arts student or a history student.
They're very vital to complementing the West Point

in our society because these officers become public servants to serve 221 million people right today and we've got a lot in order to serve those people you've got to come from a cross section of those people to serve the
for the military today, for the Army to fulfill its responsibilities to 221 million people, it's got to have an officer corps that represents all of those people.
You've got to have English majors, history, all the specific engineerings,
textile, the whole gamut.
So, do you get that from West Point?
No.
Now, where is that, but where is the rest of this supposed to come from?
It's got to come from ROTC.
That's why ROTC is so important to the military.
And you put that together, and these guys then start to school.
ROTC
graduates, West Point graduates, all start school and they continue to school throughout their entire career.
Serving at the cabinet level, become Secretary of State, become President of the United States, and all these positions.
Well, those that do that are those who have enriched themselves from all walks of life brought in by your officer corps.
So that's an important part of the ROTC officer coming in with the Army, Navy, and the Air Force academy graduates.
Now there's probably a higher percentage of senior officers in the military that are from the academies than from the ROTC programs.
Probably there is now.
Is there

I have heard from some quarters that there's some sort of a club and that the military academy people will promote their own faster than they'll promote ROTC or Texas Aggies and I was wondering if you'd respond to that.
Is there sort of a, is there that feeling or is that just about hogwash?
That's all hogwash and that comes from people
who haven't met the standards.
Or they've seen somebody been promoted over their head and they say, oh, he's from West Point or he's from the Air Academy or he's from the Naval Academy.
That's all hogwash.
As I say, I've been an instructor at West Point.
And the treatment that I received up there was absolutely phenomenal from the standpoint of me being there.
And I've been treated the same throughout my entire life with the military.
I've been promoted ahead of my contemporaries in most every instance of which were West Pointers.
So I'd say that's a bunch of hogwash.
So it's a question of the quality.
It's a question of quality, you see.
Right now the chairman and joint chief is an OCS graduate
General Vesey from Minnesota, and a personal friend of mine.
He was vice chief of staff of the Army before he moved up a few days ago, but Mr. Reagan.
This is the first time in some time that the ROTC, General Wyant,
who was the Chief of Staff before the present Chief of Staff.
He was ROTC at California.
I think that from the standpoint of your selection procedures for general officers are such that
It really doesn't make any difference whether you came up through the ranks as a private or whether you graduated from West Point or whether you graduated from Texas A&M, VMI, or the Citadel.
It doesn't make any difference because that cannot impact on what you've done.
And that's what you're being promoted on and what you've done and your potential.
So you think that most of the people who
but for such an idea are just sour grapes.
Oh, absolutely.
No question about it.
No question about it.
Now I want to ask you about something else that's a little bit more controversial, and this is an idea often suggested by the press, that there's some sort of a military mentality.
You've probably heard of that term, a military mentality, a military way to do it, which is much different than a civilian way to do it.
Is there a military mentality, and if so, would you find it?
No, I've found no military mentality.
I think that, again, we're looking for balance in the military and the ROTC product and the soldier off the street product coming up through the ranks.
disavow any militaristic approach to things.
Too many of us have served at the cabinet level.
Too many have been involved in things like trying to get two-track education systems in high school.
Can you imagine?
I sat for four years as a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for personnel, manpower and personnel.
My God, I was involved in programs that impact on our whole civilian way of life.
So you can't serve at those levels and say they're just a militaristic viewpoint.
How would you like to get involved in trying to save Chrysler Corporation back in 1953, 54, when they were about to go down the damn tube then?
I tell you, the thing I think that most people resent about the military is that there is a discipline there.
There is principles laid out on what you want to do, and there is an application of these principles in a precise manner.
which should produce the best approach to getting something done.
And all this is is orderliness.
Orderliness.
And I think there is an orderly manner of going about getting things done and the press call this a militaristic approach because this orderliness is uncommon to civilian
way of doing business.
That's exactly it as I see it.
That's exactly it.
Okay, now when you finished up at Texas A&M, did you have pretty firm ideas about what you wanted to do?
Did you want to go in the military at that time?
Did you want a civilian job?
Can you continue the story?
I worked for a little while.
as a civilian, uh, waiting for, uh, my, uh, diploma before I went to the military.
And, uh, uh, no, it was never any desire to, uh, I could have gone to work for Hughes, too, uh, but, in Houston.
But I, uh, I, uh, wanted to go to the military.
And, uh,
Some of the chaps that graduated ahead of me were second lieutenants down at Fort Sam Houston in the 2nd Infantry Division, and they had invited me down there on the weekend while I was cadet.
And at Fort Crockett in Galveston, they had a coast artillery regiment down there, and I had been invited down there.
I just was totally impressed with this.
And another thing that I had learned, and that was that there was a guy named Adolf Hitler that was playing havoc with things in Western Europe.
And since I've
That coat of arms goes back to 12th century in England, English and German extraction.
I said in my judgment, I didn't have much judgment,
But I was no different from anybody else that just graduated from college.
Because judgment comes from experience and acceptance of responsibility.
Until you've done that, you know.
He thought that maybe Hitler was... Oh, I knew he had to.
He was going to be running all over the place, and I didn't know where the end was going to be, and I figured that I might as well get in there and learn all I can before I have to go.
before I, you know, it would have given me a better break in leading the young men.
So you joined in 1940.
Yeah, I was a second lieutenant.
Received my commission, and I went straight away.
And so you were immediately assigned to the 2nd Armored Division?
At Fort Benning, Georgia.
Okay, and what was your job there?
I was a platoon leader.
Okay.
Yeah.
And then my education started.
Okay, let's talk about that.
My education at that time, this was July 1940, I was the only second lieutenant in a battalion, in a tank battalion, the third battalion of the 68th Armored Regiment Light.
And there were five other officers.
One was a battalion commander who was a major.
I guess there were four other officers.
And three company commanders who were first lieutenants.
That was all the officers there were.
Normally you have about 40 officers in there, but that's all.
I was the only non-West Pointer.
I was a second lieutenant.

And I said, well, I gotta, the major, the battalion commander, he told me, he said, now, in addition to you being platoon leader, I want you to be aid to Colonel George S. Patton at the division headquarters when you go on field maneuvers.

I want you to work with him, and I want you to be my exec, and I want you to be my supply officer, and I want you to be my personnel officer, and then my operations officer here in the battalion headquarters.
At the meantime, you're going down to I Company, and I want you to learn all there is to running a company.
Ms. Hollingsworth had graduated, just graduated from Texas A&M, I mean from TWU, and so we lived off post.
War was coming at Columbia, Columbus, South, Columbus, Georgia, Columbus, Georgia.
She didn't see very much of me except maybe
few hours on Sunday because I had about five sergeants who probably in experience for exceeded the capabilities of our PhDs today.
They were PhDs in the art of soldiering because they all had about 15 years of
eighteen year service.
First Sergeant Latham, First Sergeant Latham had about eighteen year service.

He was the first sergeant and the top sergeant and then there was Sergeant Bardinelli, he was a mess sergeant and you used to have a mess account where you got so much money and he had to manage that.
I had to learn to manage that.
He bought the food.
You got some issue food but he bought food.
for these hundred and twenty-five men in the company.
Then there was Supply Sergeant Murphy in response for all the supplies for that company.
Then there was Sergeant Heiss who was a maintenance sergeant for the seventeen tanks, four motorcycles,
three-quarter ton truck and one two-and-a-half ton truck and a mess truck.
And then there was a favorite platoon sergeant of mine named Stanford, Sergeant Stanford.
He was a tactician.
So I went to school.
I set an objective for myself, which was to drain those guys dry.
Stanford was the junior of the lot.
He only had about 14 years service.
My objective was to absorb each of those fellows
Total years of experience.
And that was a hell of an undertaking.
But I felt I had to have that.
So I called them in my later years the five great professors of my life.
Because they made me successful.
You see?

I have to accept the fact that I was successful whether I'm blowing my own horn or not but they are responsible as far as I'm concerned for me learning the real art of the trade and my father provided me and my mother
with what's necessary, with how to take that art and apply it.
That's how plain and simple it is.
What were some of the tips that they gave you?
Well, first place, they insisted that I learn all there was about each of those things, even the cooking.
The first sergeant
taught me that if a platoon of twenty-five men do something wrong don't punish the whole platoon punish or ferried out and correct the one single one responsible because all five of the tanks
went in the wrong direction.
Don't call all the crews down and reprimand them for that.
Find out who it was that somebody there to respond to that.
That's right.
That was very important early.
There was a continuation of this business of doing everything right.
In keeping a record, I'd say Sergeant Major, or Sergeant Murphy,
Why did you do this?
Why did you put a mark here?
Why are you required to use the same colored ink?
Well, you're required to use the same black ink on this and red ink over here for a simple reason.
We're talking about deficits and we're talking about credits.
You're required to have so many tent pegs in this company and this is very important because if you don't,

some guy when you go out here the in the woods and the wind is blowing and raining at night one tent peg is not there means that that one's going to blow away he said do you understand that i said why why you got why don't you what are you doing you got all of you got all the flashlights stacked over here on one side and
and you've got all the batteries stacked over here, and Colonel Patton just raised hell yesterday about us preparing for war, and we're not preparing for war.
If you've got flashlights over here and things over here, and we have to go to war in the morning, now we've got to put those together.
And somebody's liable to come in here and forget the, got the flashlights and forget the batteries.
Well, and he goes,
through about the maintenance of this equipment and why you don't want a battery to go bad in a flashlight and destroy the flashlight and all that sort of stuff.
Then in the maintenance, you learn to time the tank engines.
You learn to help take them out.
You learn all there is to know about it.
Sergeant Heiss said to me, he said, if you don't learn all this,
How do you know wherever you go from here and whatever units you have, how do you know whether or not that sergeant is snowing you or not about what's going on?
I said, I never thought about that, Sergeant Hines.
Will a sergeant do that?
He said, sergeants are people.
And people are all different, he told me.
I thought.
You're telling me something that I told my father when I was ten years old.
So these men taught you the practical trade?
Absolutely, absolutely, no question about it.
How long were you in Georgia?
I was there a year and a while, then I was sent off to
to an automotive course at Fort Knox, which was the only schooling I had after I left Texas A&M until after the war.
And what did they try to teach you at the automotive course?
To move large armored formations like the Second Armored Division with 300 plus tanks,
